value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Also another interjection hara 'look!' can be used in the same or similar function.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: No lexical entry, only found in examples.
example_as_in_source: «Ма» букIузиб алжаналла таккванал ттабичибзиб саб, «гьакка» – жагьаннабиццил
example: "ma" buk'uzib alžanalla takːʷanal tːabičibzib sab, "hakːa" - žahannabicːil
translation_as_in_source: (погов.) слово «возьми» вышло с райского балкона, а «дай» – из ада
translation: (proverb:) The word "take it!" came from Heaven's balcony, "give!" - from Hell.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Also another interjection hara 'here it is, look!' can be used in the same or similar function.
example_comment: Cf. an equivalent example with hara: гьара этти шин «на тебе вода».

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
lexical_entry / citation from the source: The interjection ma ‘take, hold’ is known in various languages of Daghestan (e.g. Archi, Agul). In Mehweb, it may attach the plural marker -na...

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Only found in examples from the book, not in the description.
translation: Here, take this abbasi {small coin}, - he says.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: There is also another functionally similar interjection hara ‘come, go, look, here is, here you are’ .
lexical_entry / citation from the source: There are two particles ma ‘take’ and hara ‘come, go, look, here is, here you are’ that are used in commands when requesting the addressee to take something or to come to the speaker. These particles thus function like verbs inflected for the imperative.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'

Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: There is variation in the form of the interjection: хӀа / хӀахьий are provided by Bekova et al. as variants, while Ozdoev cites the form хӀахьий. The word хӀа has two homonyms, according to Bekova et al.: a) "частица кстати"; b) "межд. а, вот, аха (выражает догадку, удивление)". Nichols (2011: 391) cites the interjection with nasalization: nahw, nahwii 'here' (handing something to someone).
lexical_entry / citation from the source: XIA // ХIАХЬИ (частица) на, возьми, возьмите; НА частица разг. (возьми) хӀахьий

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: The source also contains another lexical entry, hane' (2) - aba; ну-ка; well.
lexical_entry / citation from the source: hane' - aha; на; well, here you are!

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: In the grammar, the interjection is cited either without nasalization on the last vowel (p. 24, 55, 95), or with it (p. 443).
lexical_entry / citation from the source: ГЬАНЪАН (частица) 1. на, нате (сопровождает жест передачи, вручения: вот, возьми-те); 2. на тебе (выражает удивления и оценки по поводу чего-либо неожиданного)
example_comment: Cyrillic "н" is a superscript sign in the orthography of the source.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Forker (2013: 455) cites the interjection without vowel length: "Ho and ha are used when giving something to somebody, as a command to take it" (note that ha has a more general function, judging from examples).
example_comment: Cyrillic "н" is a superscript sign in the orthography of the source.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
example_comment: Cyrillic "н" is a superscript sign in the orthography of the source.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
translation: (To a child:) come, take the breast
example_comment: Cyrillic "н" is a superscript sign in the orthography of the source.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Words with nasalized vowels are rare in Tsez, and the imperative interjection is one of those (p. 425).
example_comment: Cyrillic "н" is a superscript sign in the orthography of the source.

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Not a dedicated 'here, take it!'-interjection: according to Dum-Tragut (2009: 696), "Usually the expressions <…> aha “here (you are)”, <…> sa “this, that” introduce the opinion, appraisal or conclusion".

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: According to Authier (2012: 174), gi is a regular imperative of the verb gürde 'take' ("Au singulier, la forme de l’impératif correspond normalement au thème virtuel. Toutefois, les verbes à racine terminée par n ou r le perdent à l’impératif singulier : <...> gürde ‘prendre’ → gi !). Thus it cannot be coded as a dedicated imperative interjection.
lexical_entry / citation from the source: Gİ(R) частица разг. на, нате (сопровождает жест передачи, вручения: вот, возьми)

value1_name: Phonological form of the imperative interjection 'here, take it!'
comment: Not a dedicated 'here, take it!'-interjection: also used in contexts like აჰა, მოვდივარ! ‘Here, I’m coming!’; see also examples in Electronic version of Georgian Explanatory Dictionary.
lexical_entry / citation from the source: aha (межд.) вот; aha! (ij) 1 hey!; Here you are!; 2 OG lo! (Rayfield 2006)
